data.text: Shorter Stem and Twitchy Steering

Got a professional bike fit prior to my upcoming tour. He recommended a shorter stem for a more comfortable, more upright position. This was marginally effective. However, the handlebars were more twitchy. After a few rides, got that under control. Put on rack and empty panniers and the twitchyness was back. Concerned about full load. Could you share your thoughts on stem length and front load.
The weight is slowing down the steering.

data.text: I think you got that exactly right. Mine felt "twitchy" at first too, because the shorter stem means the wheel is turning in a smaller circle [shorter radius with short stem]. Now I love it. It's essentially a kind of "cyclocross" setup on a road bike [or endurance road-bike]. The leg and back muscles seem to like it much more. No more aches and pains.

data.text: Thanks. As a mountain bike rider have played with stem/handlebar lengths. Some stems were too short and never got over the too fast steering. So I believe there is such a thing as too short. Maybe fully loaded will dampen the steering, that makes sense. As to professional fit, I am not sold. Told him my goals and he just assumed a more upright position would be more comfortable. I had rode thousands kms, including a 70 day tour....0 pain, stiffness, etc. No change in pedal height. We did dial in saddle, but I did that. Just easier with help and a stand. Got same results solo, just takes a lot longer. As to flat bars....not enough hand position. I ride mountain bike more often than touring/gravel bike. I am intrigued by butterfly bars though.
data.author: Tom Watson

data.text: 'Twitchy' is all you. Sounds like you were accustomed to an odd fit where you had to over-compensate for a poor posture, & fixing the posture gave you a sudden over-abundance of strength where you could relax a bit. Just continue to settle into it. I always want to avoid over-loading the inertia in the steering rotation so I can react easily. Keep aware of the fact that on a diamond frame a lot of balance is in micro-cantilever rotations from your feet that you normally don't think about - what I had to re-learn when I switched to a high-racer recumbent where I had to make those same micro-cantilever rotations from my hips instead of my feet.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Twitchiness will most likely be caused by not enough weight on the front wheel. Add paniers to the front and you should solve the problem. P.S. i've been fitting bikes to their owners professionally for over 30 years.
data.author: Ed Hall

data.text: I had my stem shortened about a year ago. Was very suspicious at first because now I'm no longer Tadej Pogacar in the Tour de France, just a regular (cyclo-cross-ish) dude on a bike. I find it "extremely" comfortable. I can go longer distances because of it, but it's probably slightly tougher against the wind, unless you get down on the drops. Still, 120 km feels like a breeze now. Just a wonderful ride, without having to stoop down all the time. But, I think one has to back up every so often and ask oneself: What am I doing on this bike? before even getting to the bikefit. So, I try to list the reasons: 1. Health, happiness, well-being. 2. Pandemic-era transportation and distancing while travelling. 3. Loneliness: you want to see people, somehow, some way. 4. Exploration, navigation, mapping, discovery. 5. Racing? For others, they may have different reasons: 1. To deliver groceries. 2. To walk my niece to school 9 km away. 3. Travelling about visiting friends. 4. Going fishing, and back again. 5. Just for fun, to get out a bit. 6. "Because I have nuthin better to do." 7. To help me think. 8. To get away from my wife/husband/girlfriend/boyfriend. So, whether it's an escape vehicle, or for delivering eggs, or for exercise, or for winning the Tour de France, the bike has to be fashioned into some kind of specialized instrument to achieve that purpose. If I'm training for the Tour de France, I'd go for a long stem. All other situations I'd look at shortening the stem, because doing so changes your entire body position and the way the muscles work, to make it easier (in my opinion). The alleged loss of aero also comes with a gain in comfort. The gain in comfort alone should provide more speed, even if you lose some from the loss of aero.

data.text: Over the years of working in bike shops I have encountered many different systems that purport to provide people with optimal fit on their bike. If optimal fit was science the various systems would all come to the same conclusion, they don‚Äôt. Fitting on a bike changes in the bike industry and among professional riders. My own position on my bike even changes from early Spring to late Summer as my fitness level changes. That one person who installed that one stem to fit one rider on one bike based on their one system might be wrong. It‚Äôs ok to try a new riding position for a while and then decide it doesn‚Äôt work for you. Change it again. It can take me over a year to get my position just right on a new bike.

data.text: Be careful with being too upright. There's a sweet spot for being comfortable after that you are losing so much wattage because of drag due to body position. Biggest gains on the bike are aero gains regardless you are going slow or fast. That's why a lot of tourers are getting rid of side bags and using more and more saddle and frame packs. You ride one less hour to get to your destination you'll be more comfortable and fresh.
